loans.name: Jose Francisco

texts.es: Jose de 52 años de edad posee una pequeña tienda desde hace 15 años ubicada en su lugar de residencia, tiene mucha clientela por la variedad de productos  los buenos precios, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra cubrir los gastos que se le presentan en el hogar, Don Jose vive en casa propia con su familia, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas mercadería como: pan dulce, golosinas, refrescos,  sopas, café, granos básicos, etc. y asi obtener mejores ingresos y tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Jose is 52 years old and has had a small shop for 15 years. He runs the shop out of his home and has many customers because of the variety of good products that he offers. Jose uses the money that he earns from sales to cover household costs. Jose lives with his family in a house that he owns. He is applying for a loan in order to buy more merchandise, such as sweet bread, sweets, soft drinks, soups, coffee, basic grains and more. With this loan Jose will earn a higher income and, together with his family, can enjoy a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy sweet bread, sweets, soft drinks, soups, coffee, basic grains and more.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds, manure, anti-insect treatments, fertiliser, anti-disease chemicals, tools and more, and to improve his land.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more clothes in bulk for men, women and children.

loans.name: Woetsa

texts.fr:
Woetsa vit dans une famille polygame. Elle a 2 enfants et âgée de 49 ans. Woetsa tient une boutique au marché de son quartier. Elle étale des produits alimentaires et de première nécessité. Grâce à son accueil chaleureux, sa clientèle ne cesse d’agrandir. 
Avec ce microcrédit, elle souhaite accroître sa capacité d’approvisionnement et faire plus de profit.
texts.en:
Woetsa lives in a polygamous family. She has two children and is 49 years old. Woetsa runs a shop in her neighborhood market. She displays food products and basic necessities. Thanks to her warm welcome, her clientele continues to expand.

With this micro-credit loan, she wants to increase her stock supply and make more profit.

loans.use: buy 12 bags of rice and 5 cans of vegetable oil

loans.name: Lucie

texts.fr:
Lucie vit à Adidogomé. Elle est mariée et a 49 ans. Elle a ouvert en 2000  une petite boutique des produits alimentaires. Avec ses maigres moyens, elle ravitaille sa boutique une fois par semaine pour satisfaire les demandes de ses clients.
Lucie sollicite ce crédit pour augmenter son stock et réduire les coûts de transport, par l’achat de 02 sacs de riz, 02 cartons de lait marque PEAK, 10 sacs de détergents.
texts.en:
Lucie lives in Adidogomé. She is married and is 49 years old. In 2000 she opened a small general food shop. With meager resources she resupplies her shop once a week to meet her customers' demands. 

Lucie is requesting this loan to increase her stock and reduce transportation costs by purchasing two bags of rice, two cartons of PEAK brand milk, and ten bags of detergent.

loans.use: buy 2 bags of rice, 2 cartons of milk, and 10 bags  of detergent

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena's previous loan was a big help in her business, as she was able to buy the materials needed for making rugs. Aside from this, she was also able to send her child to school.

She also operates a jeepney unit, for additional income. Together with her husband, she works hard to provide for their family's everyday needs. She would like to apply for another loan, this time 16,000 PHP. She will use the new loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her rug-making business. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her daily needs and provide for her child’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Lucena hopes to grow her business and dreams that her child will finish school. She meets up with her co-fellowship members* every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda previously accessed a 50,000 PHP loan that she used to buy fertilizer, seeds and farm inputs for her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy fertilizer, seeds and farm inputs for her business. Her profits from this business will definitely help her sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rosalinda dreams that her business will last longer and hopes to have better living conditions. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer, seeds and farm inputs for her business.

loans.name: Reynalyn

texts.en:
Reynalyn is 20 years old and single. 

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell in her store.

Reynalyn has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as bread, soft drinks, beverages and other groceries. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en:
Sherlita works hard to support her family. She is a widow and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Sherlita requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like soft drinks, biscuits, soap and other groceries. She has been in this business for two years.

In the future, Sherlita would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase more items like soft drinks, biscuits, soap and other groceries.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 40 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, etc.

Arlene has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for years and earns additional income from food vending.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, eggs, and milk

loans.name: Jose Maria

texts.es:
José María es uno de los tantos agricultores que desde muy temprano están levantados cumpliendo labores de campo para que las personas tengan cada día un plato de comida en su mesa y que tienen muy presente que es la actividad laboral más mal paga del mundo.
Cultiva café, plátano  y se dedica a la actividad de venta de animales pues los tiempos muertos de la agricultura son muy grandes y tiene que buscar la manera de generar recursos esos meses en los cuales está pereciendo la cosecha, en busca de tener un mejor cultivo fértil y más abundante el señor José María solicita un crédito para la compra de abonos, fertilizantes y su respectiva mano de obra ya que considera que ese trabajo lo debe hacer un profesional y no quiere exponer sus cultivos que no solo lo benefician a él si no a los consumidores este crédito le ayuda de gran manera a aumentar la cosecha por temporada generándole buenos recursos para cumplir el sueño de su vida el cual es ampliar la finca para tener mayor cultivo y trabajar mucho más por su esposa y poder dejarle un buen legado de tierras a sus 4 hijos.
texts.en:
José María is one of the many farmers who get up very early to work in the field so that they have a plate of food on their tables every day. It is very much in their minds that it is the most poorly paid job in the world.

He grows coffee and plantains, and he also sells animals since the downtimes in agriculture are very long and he has to look for a way to earn money in the months when the harvest is dying out. In order to have more fertile and abundant crops, José María is requesting a loan to buy compost and fertilisers. He will also pay for workers to do each respective activity since he thinks a professional should do this work and he does not wish to expose his crops [to ruin] as they will be not be profitable if the consumers do not want them. This loan is of great help to him in increasing his seasonal harvest and generating good income so he can accomplish his life dream of expanding his plantation to have more crops, working more for his wife, and being able to bequeath a decent amount of land to his four children.

loans.use: to buy compost and fertilisers and pay workers in order to have more abundant crops

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy second-hand clothing and bags.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy fabric and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase used clothing and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase sacks of corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase hair extensions and shoes to resell

loans.name: Ma. Celita

texts.en:
Ma. Celita previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to buy pork and chicken needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help with their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to purchase more pork and chicken needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Ma. Celita dreams that her business will be well established and hopes that her family is always in good condition. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week, and it is a place where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more pork and chicken needed in her business.

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante previously accessed a 19,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that he utilized to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his child and in his personal, household and business expenditures.

He would like to apply for a new 25,000 PHP loan that he will be utilizing to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in his inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain the daily needs and the educational expenses of his child. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Dante dreams to have other sources of income and hopes to give his family a better future. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week. At these meetings, he draws strength and inspiration from studying the word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy oil and cassava flour.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Luzminda owns and operates a plot of farmland, planting bananas and vegetables to earn a living. For more than five years, she was able to provide for the family. She had successfully repaid her previous loan used for buying farm chemicals. To improve the farm, she took a new loan to purchase organic fertilizer and seedlings. Luzminda aims to expand her farm to have a better income.

loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
Khoeun, a 46-year-old married woman, has worked as a farmer for 30 years. She lives in Prey Chhor District of Kampong Cham Province. Khoeun has three dependent children who are in school and three married children. She and her husband can earn around USD 10 in one day from their farming business.

This couple has received loans from Hathta Kaksekar four times already. During this time, Khoeun wants one more loan to buy a small piece of land to expend her farming business. Khoeun promises to pay the loan with the interest to Hattha Kaksekar punctually, like she has done before.

loans.use: to buy a small piece of land to expand the farm

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: La Señora Martha  tiene 40 años es casada con 3 hijos que son un hijo mayor de 19 y dos hijas de 16 y 14 años de edad, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de las denominadas "payasas", que vienen a ser colchones, elaborados de paja de monte con sacos de yute ella lo fabrica en su mismo domicilio que se encuentran en Zona Kalajahuira de la Ciudad de la Paz, este préstamo es el primer crédito que tiene con la institución, la señora Martha va a usar este préstamo para la compra de materiales como paja por mayor hilos y sacos de yute,  la señora Martha solicita crédito debido a sus necesidades,  la señora Martha enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la clientes es bastante antigua en este negocio, sin embargo la prosperidad del rubro ha hecho que varias personas se dediquen a este negocio, esto le ha generado bastante competencia y  va a utilizar los beneficios en la compra de materiales,  su deseo de la señora Martha es hacer construir ya tiene un terreno el cual por ahora está sin ninguna construcción, y de esta manera mejorará la comodidad y calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Martha, 40, is married and has three children: a son, 19, and two daughters, 16 and 14.  She makes and sells "payasas" which are mattresses made from straw and jute sacks.  She makes them at home in the Kalajahuira Zone of the city of La Paz.  This loan is her first through the institution and Maria will use it to buy materials such as wholesale straw, thread and jute sacks.

Martha is requesting the loan because of her needs.  Her challenge is getting enough customers since she has been in business for quite some time.  But the profitability of the sector means there are more people in the same business which has generated quite a lot of competition.  She will use her profits to buy materials.

Martha's goal is to build a more comfortable home on land she owns in order to improve her family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy wholesale straw, thread and jute sacks.

loans.name: Maya Balquiria

texts.es: La Señorita Maya tiene 24 años y es soltera,  estudia la carrera  de ingeniería comercial  en uno de las universidades más reconocidas  de la ciudad de La Paz, la Señorita Maya trabaja  para pagar sus estudios ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de mujer, este es su primer crédito que ha tomado con la institución,  la Señorita Maya va a usar este préstamo para  el pago de mensualidades para sus  estudios  Superiores,  la Señorita Maya enfrenta retos en su estudios que son falta de apoyo económico  por parte de sus padres y el tener que trabajar y estudiar es muy duro pero ella tiene ganas de seguir adelante superarse terminar su carrera y poder ejercer su profesión,  viven en la zona de San Antonio  su deseo es poder titularse lo antes posible para poder trabajar y así de esta manera poder tener más ingresos económicos para ayudar a su familia y a sus hermanos a salir adelante.
texts.en:
Maya, 24, is single and studying toward a commercial engineering degree at one of the best known universities in the city of La Paz.  She works to pay for her education by selling women's clothing.  This is her first loan through the institution.

Maya will use the loan to pay for her monthly education expenses.  The challenges she faces are the lack of economic support from her parents and having to work and study at the same time, which is very difficult.  She is determined to get ahead and finish her education so she can work in her profession.  She lives in the area of San Antonio.  Her desire is to graduate as soon as possible so she can work and earn more income to help her family and siblings to get ahead.

loans.use: To pay monthly expenses.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es: Maria de 33 años de edad se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de productos de uso personal como desodorantes, maquillaje, cremas y también ropa, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en el mercado que se encuentra cerca de su lugar de residencia, es madre soltera vive con sus dos hijos y su madre en casa propia, Maria está solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas mercadería por mayor y seguir con sus ventas que le generan buenas ganancias y asi poderle dar a su familia una mejor vida sin limitación alguna.
texts.en:
Maria, 33, sells all kinds of personal products such as deodorant, make-up, creams and clothing.  Her business is located in the market which is near her home.  She is a single mother and lives with her two children and her mother in her own home.

Maria is requesting a loan to buy more wholesale merchandise and continue with sales to earn a nice profit.  This will allow her to give her family a better lifestyle without any limitations.

loans.use: To buy wholesale deodorants, make-up, creams and clothing.

loans.name: Salvadora

texts.es: Salvadora de 33 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con su hijo,  ella se dedica a la venta de refrescos, jugos, agua, etc. su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, posee mucha clientela, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Salvadora está solicitando a INTEGRAL un crédito para comprar más productos por mayor y poder seguir con sus ventas y tener junto con su hijo una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Salvadora, 33, is a single mother who lives in her own home with her son.  She earns a living selling sodas, juices, water, etc.  Her business is set up in her home where she attends to many customers; so she is able to use her income to cover household expenses.

Salvadora is requesting a loan through INTEGRAL to buy more wholesale products and continue with sales so she and her son can enjoy a better lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy wholesale sodas, juices, water, etc.

loans.name: Noe Eriberto

texts.es: Noe de 50 años de edad vive en casa propia con su familia, el se dedica a la compra y venta de semillas de marañón comercializa sus productos por los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, Noe está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas de marañón por mayor para continuar con sus ventas y poder obtener mejores ingresos y asi darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Noe, 50, lives in his own house with his family.  He buys and sells cashew nuts at different markets near his home.  Noe is requesting a loan to buy wholesale cashew nuts so he can continue his sales and earn more income to give his family a better lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy wholesale cashew nuts.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more grocery items for her variety store. Her loan was also used in her canteen and on her farm. Her income from her businesses is assisting with her everyday household expenditures. She continues to work hard to provide for her everyday needs.

Virginia would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan so she can buy grocery items, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory: the more items displayed in her store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Virginia will also use the loan in her canteen and on her farm. Her profits from her businesses will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Virginia hopes that her business will continue to flourish and dreams of being successful in life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items, toiletries, beverages and other products

loans.name: Resse

texts.en:
Resse, aged 35, is a married woman with two children who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Resse has had a dried fish vending business in the Philippines for 10 years. 

Resse successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. She has requested a PHP 29,500 loan  through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

In the future, Resse would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa, aged 29, is married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. Elisa has run a general store in the Philippines for the past two years and also earns an income from food vending. 

Elisa has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items like canned goods, eggs, soap, chips, bread, etc. to sell. 

Elisa aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items like canned goods, eggs, soap, chips, bread, etc. to sell

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
Socorro works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a buy-and-sell gadgets business in the Philippines for the past three years.

Socorro has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional gadgets like cellphones, tables, etc. to sell.

She would like to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase additional gadgets like cellphones, tables, etc. to sell

loans.name: Genora

texts.en:
Genora works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a food vending business in the Philippines for the past 22 years.

Genora has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase rice, milk, young coconut, sugar, etc.

In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase rice, milk, young coconut, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur SIAKA est né en mars 1980 à SIKASSO, marié,  père de 2 enfants, il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à HAMDALLAYE un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso  troisième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Monsieur SIAKA après avoir mené beaucoup d’activité sans succès,  s’est initié aux activités d’achat et vente des charbons des bois, des bois de chauffage dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso et il dispose de son propre tracteur. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est a son septième prêt individuel, les prêt précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce septième prêt, il compte acheter avec son tracteur 10 chargements de charbons de bois, 8 chargements de bois de chauffage et des pièces de recharges et  l’entretien de son tracteur, 
 Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 195 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Siaka was born in March 1980 in Sikasso. He is married and father to two children, and he lives with his wife and their children in a large traditional family in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class districts of the town of Sikasso, the Republic of Mali's third administrative region.

Having already had a number of unsuccessful activities, Siaka began buying and selling charcoal and firewood in the towns surrounding Sikasso, and he also has his own tractor. He is in great demand from his customers for the quality of his products. With a view to being able to satisfy his ever-growing customer base more easily, he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, and is on his seventh individual loan from the institution; the previous loans have been repaid in full.

With this seventh loan he is planning to buy with his tractor ten loads of charcoal, eight loads of firewood and some spare parts for his tractor; he will also pay for the maintenance of his tractor.

He expects to make a monthly profit of 195,000FCFA, which will be used to expand his business, to contribute to family expenses and to repay the interest on his loan.

loans.use: to buy charcoal, firewood and spare parts for his tractor.

loans.name: Kholis

texts.en: Kholis is a kind man. He is a careful father and responsible husband. Kholis and his wife are teachers. They work in a local school. Kholis and his wife always try to help their children to get a higher education. Kholis’s two children are students. Now, he needs financial support because he must pay for his son’s tuition at the university. He is asking for a loan of 600 USD to pay for his son’s education. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To pay for the education of his son

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Soeun is a 57-year-old married woman who lives and operates a farming business in Svay Antor District, Prey Veng Province.  She has been in this business for more than 10 years, earning approximately USD 2.50 a day. She has 5 children, three of whom are already married. Farming is the main job that she operates to support her family.

Soeun said that she is grateful to Kiva and the partners, because through them she was able to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a loan to build a hygienic latrine. This loan will improve her general living conditions, promote health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. She is grateful for the loan granted through HKL, which has a much lower interest rate than the usual for this kind of loan product.

loans.use: to build a hygienic latrine

loans.name: Takku Liggey Same 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Takku Liggey Sam, rassemble cinq femmes qui évoluent toute dans le secteur du  commerce. Elles se connaissent parce qu’habitant le même village et ont formé un groupe de crédit parce s’entendant entre elles. 
La présidente, la dame Coura, s’active dans le commerce de divers produits, des chaussures et de la vaisselle. Elle a une expérience de plus de cinq ans dans ce domaine et sollicite ce crédit aussi bien pour accompagner ses copines qui lui ont demandé d’être à leur tête et cela lui permettra aussi de renouveler sa marchandise pour satisfaire sa clientèle. 
Avec ses revenus, elle appuie son mari dans la gestion de la dépense quotidienne.
Elle veut ouvrir un magasin un jour et diversifier ses produits.
texts.en:
The Takku Liggey Same 6 group is made up of five women who all work in commerce. They know each other, because they live in the same town. And they they formed a loan group together because they all get along. 

The president, Coura, works selling various goods, such as shoes and dishes. She has been doing this for more than five years and is seeking a loan, with the other group members, in order to re-new her stock so as to better satisfy her customers.

With the earnings, she will support her husband and help with the everyday expenses.

She would like to open a store one day and diversify her products.

loans.use: to buy various goods to resell: shoes, dishes, food products

loans.name: Sokngim

texts.en:
Sokngim, aged 44, is a widow who lives in Prey Chhor District of Kampong Cham Province. She has seven children, three of whom are already married. Sokgnim has been involved in her farming business for more than 20 years earning a daily income of USD4. Her farming business is the only source of her income.

Through already being a client of Hattha Kaksekar (HKL) three times, Sokgnim is considered as an honest customer and a dutiful woman. Now, she would like to have one more loan to buy a motorbike for the lovely children in her family to occasionally use. She is grateful for the loan granted through HKL which has a much lower interest rate than the usual rate for this kind of loan product.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy dried and smoked fish to resell

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is married with four children, and runs a general store to earn a living. She has been selling grocery goods for more than seven years and earns well for her family. Her husband also earns money from their farm, their main source of income. 

Milagros had successfully repaid her previous loan which was used for her store. She took out a new loan recently to buy more grocery goods to resell. In the future, she wants to improve her business and hopes to provide her family with a better living situation in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods to resell.

loans.name: Merah

texts.en: Merah has been operating her own retail store for more than five years and she earns well from this.  The couple had to work hard with determination of having better income to provide their child better education. To improve sales, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. In the future, Merah hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 31 years old and single. She is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Teresita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Teresita has been in pig fattening for 3 years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Teresita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is a married woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Violeta is 39 years old and has three children who are currently in school.

Violeta has a business buying and selling ready-to-wear clothes business in the Philippines. Violeta requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more stocks of ready-to-wear clothes to sell to her customers.

Violeta has been in this business for 4 years. In the future, Violeta would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of ready-to-wear clothes to sell to her customers

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en:
Zosima is 57 years old, widowed and has seven children, two of whom attend school. 

Zosima is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Zosima requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Zosima has been in pig fattening for 4 years now, and has borrowed 3 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Zosima would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Behilla

texts.en:
Behilla is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell to her customers.

Behilla has been in this business for 14 years. Behilla also earns income from charcoal retailing.

Behilla has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 40-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Janet has a business buying and selling mangoes in the Philippines. Janet requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more mangoes to sell in her fruit stand.

Janet has been in this business for 3 years. In the future, Janet would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more mangoes to sell in her fruit stand

loans.name: Josbeth

texts.en:
Josbeth, aged 37, is married with five children, four of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur and has had a fishing business in the Philippines for the past 15 years. 

Josbeth has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Soutoura 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe SOUTOURA 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à FARAKOBA un village dans la commune de LOULOUNI dans la région de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne  avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : d’arachide  avec madame ROKIA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme SOUTOURA 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir : 0,75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  105 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Soutoura 1 group are married women who, on average, are 39 years old and have four children. They mostly live in traditional families in Farakoba, one of the villages in the Loulouni commune, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth group loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Rokia, standing first from the left in the photo, grows groundnuts. With her loan, she plans to buy two 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer, two drums of herbicide and to pay the costs of labor to farm a 3/4 hectare of land.

After the harvest, crops will be sold in the village and at a market in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Rokia hopes to earn an average profit of 105,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow her to pay back her part of the loan and its interest and also help her husband with their family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy seeds, farm inputs, and fertilizer and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Sabougnouma 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 8 membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMA 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à SIRAKOROBOUGOU un village dans la commune de LOULOUNI dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage.

La spéculation cultivée est de riz  avec madame DIALIA débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  SABOUGNOUMA 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  0, 5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  73 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son interêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Sabougnouma 1 group are married women who, on average, are 42 years old and have four children. They mostly live in traditional families in Sirakorobougou, one of the villages in the Loulouni commune, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Dialia, standing first from the right in the photo, grows rice. With her loan, she plans to buy one 50-kilogram sac of fertilizer, and one drum of herbicide, and to pay the cost of labor to farm a 1/2 hectare of land.

After the harvest crops will be sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Dialia hopes to earn an average profit of 73,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow her to pay back her part of the loan and its interest and also to help her husband take care of their family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Soutoura 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe SOUTOURA 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à FARAKOBA un village dans la commune de LOULOUNI dans la région de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne  avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : d’arachide  avec madame ADIARA débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme SOUTOURA 3. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  73 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Soutoura 3 group are married women, who average 40 years of age and who have an average of four children each. The majority of them live in traditional families in Farakoba, a village in the Loulouni municipality, which lies in the Sikasso region (Mali's third administrative region).

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, so that they can carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their eighth seasonal loan from Soro Yiriwaso and the previous loans have all been repaid in full. 

Within the Soutoura 3 group, Adiara, who is standing second from the left in the photo, grows groundnut. With her loan she is planning to buy one 50 kilo sack of fertiliser and one container of weedkiller; she will also pay the labor costs for maintaining 0.5 hectares of land. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and at the market in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. She expects to make an average profit of 73,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her on the one hand to repay her loan and the interest on it, and on the other to help her husband with the family's daily outgoings.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, inputs and seeds, and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Munojot

texts.en:
Munojot, aged 28, is a hard-working young woman who has a services business in north Tajikistan. She is not married and lives with her parents. Munojot has a beauty salon and provides services as a hairdresser. 

She also provides a rental service in which she rents wedding dresses to fiancées. Munojot has been busy with this business for more than four years. She has 20 wedding dresses as her working capital. Now Munojot is going to increase the number of wedding dresses. She is asking for a loan of 3,000 Somoni to buy wedding dresses to rent. She awaits your generosity.

loans.use: To buy wedding dresses to rent

loans.name: Soutoura 4 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe SOUTOURA 4 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à FARAKOBA un village dans la commune de LOULOUNI dans la région de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage.

Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 2 bidons d’herbicide et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  0,75 hectare.

Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Soutoura 4 group are married women, who average 33 years of age and who have an average of three children each. The majority of them live in traditional families in Farakoba, a village in the Loulouni municipality, which lies in the Sikasso region (Mali's third administrative region).

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, so that they can carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their eighth seasonal loan from Soro Yiriwaso and the previous loans have all been repaid in full. 

Within the Soutoura 4 group, Alimata, who is sitting in the middle of the photo, grows groundnut. With her loan she is planning to buy two 50 kilo sack of fertiliser and two containers of weedkiller; she will also pay the labor costs for maintaining 0.75 hectares of land. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and at the market in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. She expects to make an average profit of 86,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her on the one hand to repay her loan and the interest on it, and on the other to help her husband with the family's daily outgoings.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, inputs and seeds as well as to cover labor costs.

loans.name: Lolakhon

texts.en:
Lolakhon is the caring mother of six children. She lives with her husband and children in a house which is in bad condition. Lolakhon has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 10 years. She feeds milking cows so she can sell milk and milk products to local people. Lolakhon manages her business on her own. 

Lolakhon is always trying to improve her family's living conditions. She is going to repair her house as it is in bad condition. She is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni to buy building materials such as cement, wood, paint, etc. She awaits your generosity.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement, wood, paint, etc.

loans.name: Robelyn

texts.en: Robelyn has been operating her own retail store for more than five years and she earns well from this.  Having a big family, she needs to make more efforts to provide for their needs, especially her four children. The couple have to work hard to provide their children with a better education. To improve sales, she took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. In the future, Robelyn hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase materials like fabric, nails, foam and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy materials like fabric, nails, foam and other materials needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Salve hopes to have other sources of income and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week, where she finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for materials like fabric, nails, foam and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Nemi

texts.en:
Nemi is 32 years old, married and lives with her family in her own house. They live in the Province of Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. The people in this community work in agriculture, commerce and raise livestock.

Nemi and her husband have been offering transportation services for more than 5 years.  She is an enterprising mother. She has requested a loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy spare parts like oil and lubricants for her vehicle and in this way make more money for her family.

In the future, Nemi hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts like oil and lubricants for her vehicle

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina previously accessed a 50,000 PHP loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy gardening materials like wire, baskets and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer needed in her business. Her profits from this business will definitely help her sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Josefina dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes to have a better standard of living. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for gardening materials such as wire, baskets and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer needed in her business.

loans.name: Lowella

texts.en:
Lowella works hard to support her family. Lowella is married and has a business buying and selling mangoes in the Philippines.

Lowella requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more mangoes to sell.

Lowella has been in this business for 3 years now.

Lowella would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more mangoes to sell

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is 51 years old, married and has five children, two of whom are currently in school.

Francisca is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Francisca requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Francisca has been in pig fattening for 3 years now, and has borrowed 9 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Francisca would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is 46 years old and married with three children.  With one child in school, Lilibeth works very hard to provide for them.

Lilibeth's business and family home was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Lilibeth has restarted her business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Lilibeth has taken a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Lilibeth is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Ma. Gessel

texts.en:
Ma. Gessel is 39 years old, married and has seven children, three of whom are in school.

Ma. Gessel and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Ma. Gessel is taking out a housing loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Ma. Gessel has been an NWTF borrower since 2013. 

With your help, Ma. Gessel can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In future she would like to save enough money to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Sabougnouma 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 8 membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMA 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à SIRAKOROBOUGOU un village dans la commune de LOULOUNI dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali.

They mostly live in traditional families in Sirakorobougou, a village in the Loulouni commune, in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Sali, seated first from the right in the photo, grows rice. With her loan, she plans to buy one 50-kilogram sac of fertilizer and one drum of herbicide, and to pay the cost of labor to farm a 1/2 hectare of land.

After the harvest crops will be sold in the village and in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Sali hopes to earn an average profit of 73,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow her to pay back her part of the loan and its interest, and also help her husband take care of their family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide, and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma and her husband operate their own farm for a living. She has been helping him for more than eleven years and they earn well for the family. She successfully repaid her previous loans used for their farm through her generated income. She had put up a capital for her retail store and made house improvements as she receive more income from her farm.  She took a new loan recently to buy additional grocery goods to sell. In the future, Wilma wants to have a better life for the entire family.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Milona

texts.en:
Milona previously accessed a 27,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise and products needed in her business. Her earnings are a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 35,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Milona hopes that her business will continue to be successful and dreams of giving her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. She also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her business and is now requesting a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor so she can build a house for her family.

With your help Virginia will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner.

In the future, she would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Mena is 44 years old and married with three children, all of whom attend school, Mena works very hard to provide for them.

Mena runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items like snack foods, coffee, sugar, soft-drinks, noodles and detergent soap to sell.

Mena has been in this business for 8 years and sells a variety of items. She successfully repaid her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

In the future, Mena would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like snack foods, coffee, sugar, soft-drinks, noodles and detergent soap to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth works hard to support her family. Elizabeth is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Elizabeth requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Elizabeth has been in this business for 7 years now.

Elizabeth would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Wegnogoton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 membres du groupe WEGNOGOTON 1 sont des hommes mariés et une femme mariée  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à DOUMANABA un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils, elles  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils, elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : de maïs  avec monsieur SINALY débout à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme et de femme WEGNOGOTON 1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 8 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir : 2 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  232 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Wegnogoton 1 group are married men and one married woman who, on average, are 38 years old and have five children. They mostly live in traditional families in Doumanaba, one of the villages in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the winter. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Sinaly, standing second from the right in the photo, grows corn. With his loan, he plans to buy eight 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 20 drums of different herbicides, and to pay the costs of labor to farm two hectares of land.

After the harvest, crops will be sold in the village and at a market in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit.

Sinaly hopes to earn an average profit of 232,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings will allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest, and also help to cover his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and farm inputs, and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Wegnogoton 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 membres du groupe WEGNOGOTON 2 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont en moyenne 6 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à DOUMANABA un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils, elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : de maïs  avec monsieur ADAMA débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme et de femme WEGNOGOTON 2. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 25 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir : 3 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  322 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Wegnogoton 2 group are married men who, on average, are 40 years old and have six children. They are mostly living in traditional families in Doumanaba, one of the villages in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan, and their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

Adama, standing first from the right in the photo, grows corn. With his loan, he plans to buy 16 50-kilogram sacs of fertilizer and 25 drums of different herbicides, and to pay the cost of labor to farm three hectares of land.

After the harvest crops will be sold in the village and at a market in Sikasso to male and female customers for cash and credit. 

Adama hopes to earn an average profit of 322,000 francs CFA per harvest. These earnings allow him to pay back his part of the loan and its interest, as well as helping to take care of his family's everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, and farm inputs, and to pay the cost of labor

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à TANAKABOUGOU un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide  avec madame NAHAWA assise à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  BENKADI 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir 0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  73 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women, who average 39 years of age and have an average of four children each. The majority of them live in traditional families in Tanakabougou, a village in Sikasso circle (Mali's third administrative region).

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, so that they can carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their third seasonal loan from Soro Yiriwaso and the previous loans have all been repaid in full. 

Within the Benkadi 1 group, Nahawa, who is sitting second from the right in the photo, grows groundnut. With her loan she is planning to buy one 50 kilo sack of fertiliser and one container of weedkiller; she will also pay the labor costs for maintaining 0.5 hectares of land. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. She expects to make an average profit of 73,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her on the one hand to repay her loan and the interest on it, and on the other to help her husband with the family's daily outgoings.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and weedkillers and cover labor costs.

loans.name: Wegnogoton 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 membres du groupe WEGNOGOTON 3 sont des hommes mariés   ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à DOUMANABA un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils, elles  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : de maïs  avec monsieur BREHIMA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme et de femme WEGNOGOTON 3. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 25 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente et payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir : 3 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  322 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Wegnogoton 3 group are married men, who average 41 years of age and who have an average of five children each. The majority of them live in traditional families in Doumanaba, a village in the Sikasso circle (Mali's third administrative region).

They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, so that they can carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their fifth loan for growing corn from Soro Yiriwaso and the previous loans have all been repaid in full. 

Within the Wegnogoton 3 group, Brehima, who is standing second on the far left in the photo, grows corn. With his loan he is planning to buy sixteen 50 kilo sacks of fertiliser and 25 containers of different quality weedkiller; he will also pay the labor costs for maintaining three hectares of land. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and at the market in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. He expects to make an average profit of 322,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable him on the one hand to repay his loan and the interest on it, and on the other to contribute to the family's daily outgoings.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, inputs and seeds and to cover labor costs.

loans.name: Oscar David

texts.es:
Oscar tiene 30 años de edad, estudió hasta noveno grado ya que su familia no tenía los recursos económicos para que él y junto a sus hermanos continuaran estudiando, por esta razón se tuvo trabajar a temprana edad. Él está casado y su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos, tiene 3 hijos todos menores de edad, y ellos junto con su esposa son los únicos que dependen de Oscar.

Oscar se dedica a trabajar de albañil en construcciones, el trabajo lo aprendió gracias a su padre pues él también desarrolla la misma actividad y desde que estaba pequeño le inculcó este trabajo, además de dedicarse a esta actividad también se dedica a la agricultura, en la siembra de granos básicos maíz y frijol, él se levanta a las cuatro de la mañana   para poder salir y tomar el bus para ir a su trabajo que le queda un poco retirado de su vivienda, y en el trabajo agrícola se involucran sus hijos y su esposa.

El préstamo lo necesita para comprar abono, semilla e insumos agrícolas y también pagar la mano de obra, gracias al préstamo cubrirá una necesidad que tenia de cultivar y cosechar granos para la alimentación de su familia.

Oscar planea para el futuro construir su propia casa para vivir cómodamente con su  familia, también tener un mejor y también para sus hijos desea que sigan estudiando.
texts.en:
Oscar is 30 years old, he studied until 9th grade as his family didn't have the financial resources to allow him and his siblings to continue to go to school. For this reason, he had to work at an early age. He is married and his wife works doing domestic chores. He has three young children, and they and his wife are the only ones dependent on Oscar.

Oscar works as a construction worker, he learnt the trade thanks to his father as he also worked in the trade and since he was young, taught him this trade. Besides working in this trade, he also farms, growing the staple grains corn and beans. He gets up at four o'clock in the morning to be able to take the bus to go to work, which is a bit far from his home. In his agricultural work his children and wife help out.

He needs this loan loan to buy fertilizer, seeds and farming supplies, and pay for manual labor. Thanks to the loan he will afford a necessity which he needs to grow and harvest grains to feed his family.

Oscar plans in the future to build his own home to live comfortably with his family, also to have a better life and he hopes that his children will continue to go to school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and farming supplies, and pay for manual labor.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda has been running a business buying and selling in order to provide for the needs of her family. She sells assorted groceries in their village to make a living. Her husband helps her in operating her business if he has no work as a driver. 

To improve sales, she borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase more grocery goods to resell. In the future, Belinda wants to improve the general living situation of the entire family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods.

loans.name: Adelito

texts.en:
Adelito has been providing transportation services in his community for more than five years. He earns well from this in addition to balut-vending, the main source of income. Adelito successfully repaid his previous loan used for the motorcycle repair out from his  income. 

Recently, he took a new loan new to buy more eggs used to make balut which he sells. In the future, he wants to sustain his transportation business while having more balut-vending outlets and wants to save his profit to use when he gets old.

loans.use: to buy more eggs used to make balut.

loans.name: Angelyn

texts.en:
Angelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase ingredients for her food production business.

Angelyn has been in this business for 5 years. Angelyn earns additional income from raising pigs.

Angelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Emarjorie

texts.en:
Emarjorie works hard to support her family. Emarjorie is married and has a business making dried fish in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional baskets of fish to make dried fish.

Emarjorie has been in this business for 5 years now.

In the future, Emarjorie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional baskets of fish to make dried fish.

loans.name: Jennylyn

texts.en:
Jennylyn works hard to support her family. Jennylyn is single and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase a fishing net, gasoline and other fishing materials for her business.

Jennylyn has been in this business for years now, and also earns additional income from buying and selling rice.

In the future, Jennylyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing net, gasoline and other fishing materials for her business.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 46 years old and married with six children.  With three children in school, Zenaida works very hard to provide for them.

Zenaida's business and family home were destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Zenaida has restarted her business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Zenaida has taken a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using the this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Zenaida is committed to rebuild her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla is 50 years old, married and has four children.  

She and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Perla is taking out a housing loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Perla has been an NWTF borrower since 2013.

With your help, Perla can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In future, she  would like to save enough money to build her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en:
Cerina is 43 years old and married with five children. With three children in school, Cerina works very hard to provide for them.

Cerina's business and family home were destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Cerina has restarted her business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Cerina has taken a PHP 10,000 housing loan through NWTF to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using the this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Cerina is committed to rebuild her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Rinad Group

texts.en:
Rinad is a group which comprises of four women from Sana'a, Yemen. They are requesting a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB.

Somia is the leader of the group. She is a 34-year-old married woman. She studied till the Secondary school, but she couldn't complete her studies. Somia's husband is an employee in a private sector. He is very dynamic and works hard in order to improve the living standards of his family. The salary which he receives from his job is not enough to cover all the expenses of the family. Somia says that her house lacks a refrigerator, and she can't afford this thing. Inside the kitchen of her house, Rinda puts many kinds of drinks, foods, sweets, and vegetables without a refrigerator where they need to be in a cold condition. Particularly, the climate these days is very hot. Unfortunately, she doesn't have a refrigerator in order to keep all those items in a cold condition. As a result, most of those foods and drinks expire quickly. For this reason, Somia is requesting a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a refrigerator for the house.

Somia looks forward to improving the condition of her family. She hopes to open a saving account in AMB. Her dreams in the future are to furnish her house with new furniture and home appliances.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator for the house.

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
To make a living, Ethel manages her own business weaving and selling nipa (palm leaves) in her village.  Having done this for more than four years, she was able to support the needs of her family and successfully repay her previous loan from GDMPC used for the business. 

She has had many costumers as a result of her quality products and services.  She took a new loan recently to buy additional palm leaves to cater to orders and demand.

In the future, Ethel wants to improve and expand her business to gain more income for the family.

loans.use: to buy additional palm leaves.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy additional used clothes needed in her “ukay-ukay” business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in covering personal, household and business expenditures.

Analiza would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan to buy more quality used clothes to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her income from the business will definitely help her to meet her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial assistance with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Analiza hopes that her business will continue to flourish and she desires to save for a house and lot. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every weekand draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional quality used clothes needed in her business.

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena is 38 years old and married with four children.  She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines.  Ma. Elena is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional feed for her pigs.

In addition to raising pigs, Ma. Elena also earns additional income from buying and selling dried fish.  She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Marilou works hard to support her family.  She operates a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling gasoline and rice.  Marilou is borrowing 14,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase a fishing net for her fishing business.

Marilou has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing net.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle is 27 years old with three children.

Michelle works hard to provide for her family. She sells gasoline in the Philippines and requested a 8000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell.

Michelle has borrowed and paid 1 loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her gasoline business for 1 year and also earns an income from fishing.

Michelle aspires to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional gallons of gasoline to sell

loans.name: Reyna Evelyn

texts.es:
